data.title: Docs-update: AnimatedSprite, AnimatedSprite3D (unfinished)
Defining a TooltipPanel or a TooltipLabel in a theme does not affect themed controls
data.body:
Windows 10 64bit Godot 2.1-beta

When applying a theme with TooltipPanel or TooltipLabel defined to a Control with tooltip text - the tooltip has default styling if some of parent Controls have no theme (or is overriden).

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a control of any type (eg. a panel)
2. Create a nested control of any type (eg. a button)
3. Create a theme and attach it to the button
4. Add Class Items TooltipPanel or TooltipLabel (any or both)
5. Modify properties so that they could be easily noticed
6. Add a tooltip text to the button
7. Run the scene, hover over the element, the tooltip is using default styling

Also, in the element preview area for theme editing there is no tooltip element. My suggestion - add a dedicated tooltip element or attach tooltip texts to every element previewed.

EDIT: I've encountered this issue with a more complex hierarchy, so perhaps my issue laid somewhere else. My tooltip refused to change unless I changed the theme for VBoxContainer, while my tooltipped buttons were contained deeper in panels (which were styled).

data.title: [RichTextLabel] incorrect position in parent
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** Windows 10 - Godot 2.1-beta

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I have a simple scene with one Node2D object as "root" and I resized it to full cover the 2D area of the Camera. Then I created a RichTextLabel node as a child. The child node is not correctly positioned by default. Shouldn't it be centered having the center of it's bounding rect in the center of its parent?
Here's a screenshot: https://s31.postimg.org/dfdxfuiej/Rich_Text_Label.png

Note: the bug is also present in 2.0-stable, 2.0.3 and 2.0.4.1_stable

**Steps to reproduce:**

data.title: RawArray needs a slicing operation
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot v2.1.beta

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
RawArray supports adding chunks onto the end but missed an operation to obtain a copied slice of a larger RawArray to a new (smaller) RawArray.  Of course this could be done in a loop but things like that may be a bit inefficient doing in script, especially for larger RawArray's.  C++ optimized assembly FTW.

Proposed prototype (-1 means end of the array):

RawArray RawArray.slice(start,end=-1)

Copies a slice of the original RawArray and returns a new RawArray containing the subsection, from start to end (or -1 to slice to the end).

```
# example to use proposed RawArray.slice
func skipN(origRaw,N):
    # returns new RawArray with first N bytes of original RawArray skipped
   return origRaw.slice(N)
```

data.title: dear imgui (ImGui) Integration
data.body:
Hi. So I came across this images (at the bottom) that use imgui for quick debugging in game. I'm been looking into imgui and it seems to be a really nice approach to test stuff in game. Like switching states in a FSM, scroll-bars for, I don't know, setting a scale or the health. You name it it, I think they are really useful.

I know you guys are already very busy. But I just wanted to drop this idea in here.

Here is [dear imgui](https://github.com/ocornut/imgui) which is "Bloat-free Immediate Mode Graphical User interface for C++ with minimal dependencies" and uses MIT License. So since it's in C++, would it be difficult to integrate it into godot? (I really don't know)

Anyways, what you guys think?

![](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CnUNmiyUEAAsbLD.jpg)
(ignore the shapes...)

![](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CnUONgaW8AAbJNk.jpg)

![](http://i.imgur.com/iQibpSk.gif)

data.title: Refactoring: The great API review
data.body:
Since for 3.0 a big compatibility breakage is expected, it will be a perfect time to review the API to rename confusing stuff, create/remove singletons, and also standardizing names across the different classes.
## Confusing names
- `set_hidden()` from `CanvasItem` and the corresponding property, which is `visibility/visible` (#5531).
- `is_visible()`/`is_hidden()`, which sound the same but do different things.
- `pressed`/`released` signals from `BaseButton`, which does not really do what it sounds like. They should be renamed to `button_{down,up}` (#4625, #5262).
- `CheckBox` inherits `Button`, which means it has `is_pressed()` method instead of a more natural `is_checked()`.
- `Input.get_mouse_speed()` returns the speed of the _last non-null_ mouse motion, not the current one. It could be renamed to `Input.get_last_mouse_speed()` or similar.
- `Tween.set_speed()` is confusing as it returns a scale, could be renamed to `set_speed_scale()` (#2060) Same with the property (#6935).

## Singletons/Classes to split
- `OS`, which has generic functions.
  - Move to `Engine` singleton:
    - `get_main_loop()`
    - `is_debug_build()`
    - `dump_{memory,resources}_to_file()`
    - `{get,set}_iterations_per_second()`
    - `{get,set}_target_fps()`
    - `{get,set}_time_scale()`
    - `get_engine_version()`
## Functions to move
- `Dictionary.parse_json()` -> `String.parse_json()`, since JSON can be dictionaries, arrays, or single values (#382, #3011, #4232).
## Functions to change
- `DirAccess::list_dir_begin` should return `Error` like other functions of this kind.
## Functions to remove
- `OS.set_video_mode()` (https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/3778#issuecomment-233447010).
- `OS.get_fullscreen_mode_list()` (https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/4624#issuecomment-218515473).
## Properties to remove
- `Expand` from `TextureFrame`. The `Strech Mode` property is much more flexible and can do some things that already override the `Expand` settings.

data.title: Tooltips blinking
data.body:
This is a duplicate of previous issues which have been closed without fully fixing the problem (#1959 #3835 #4667 #4686 #4713).

**Operating system:**
Windows 10 Pro 64bit 1511 Build 10586.420

**Godot versions:**
- 2.0.4.1 stable 32bit
- 2.0.4.1 stable 64bit
- 2.1-beta 20160712 32bit
- 2.1-beta 20160712 64bit

**Issue description:**
Tooltips on buttons blink on and off when mouse is not moving.
Tooltip stops blinking if mouse is moved, but only as long as the mouse pointer stays over the element that initially showed the tooltip.
Tooltip state stays unchanged, whether on or off, as long as the mouse keeps moving.
When mouse stops moving, the tooltip starts flashing again.
Sometimes, when switching to another application, the tooltip stays on in the Editor.
Sometimes, tooltips just won't disappear even when the mouse pointer is over other parts of the interface.
Changing tooltip_delay to a high value (like 10 seconds) may prevent tooltips from showing at all.

![Tooltip blinking](http://i.imgur.com/RgLpW30.gif)
Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4tgtaQ0cLUo

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a project
Open project in editor
Mouse over any button with a tooltip
Leave mouse pointer over the button
Tooltip regularly blinks on and off
Slightly move the mouse over the button
Tooltip stops flashing
Stop moving the mouse
Tooltip starts flashing again

Alt+Tab to another application
Mouse over any button with a tooltip
Just as tooltip shows, rapidly move mouse outside of Editor window
Tooltip stays visible, without flashing

**Link to minimal example project**
Behavior shows with empty project
Default tooltip_delay is 0.7 sec.

**Suspected culprits**
The software "CleanMem Mini Monitor Free" seems to enable this behavior on Windows 8.1 (but is not the only one).
The behavior seems to be related to root window handling, and/or mouse event handling.
Suspicious code lines at https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/master/scene/main/viewport.cpp#L2275

```
    if (gui.tooltip == p_control)
        gui.tooltip=NULL;
    if (gui.tooltip == p_control) {
        gui.tooltip=NULL;
        _gui_cancel_tooltip();
    }
```

(the second `if` seems to be a failed copy&paste, I'm not really sure what would be the correct way to fix it)

**Notes**
The blinking detected on Windows 10 is slower, and has a different pattern, than that detected under Windows 8.1.
Blinking speed seems to depend on something external to Godot.

data.title: Plugins don't show up in Editor settings
data.body:
**Windows - 2.0.4.1.stable.official (Steam version):**

Plugins don't show up as available in the editor settings. According to the docs and information I read elsewhere, they should show up if there's a plugin.cfg in either `res://addons/<plugin name>/` or (on windows) `$env:APPDATA/godot/plugins/<plugin name>/`. I have tried both with self made plugins following the plugin tutorial in the docs, as well as plugins I grabbed from github, and neither seemed to work even after refreshing the plugin list.

**Attempt to install any plugin**

**Link to minimal example project https://github.com/hanst99/godot_bug_demonstration**

I'm naturally not sure if this is a genuine bug or a documentation bug or if my assumptions about how this works are just wrong.

data.title: A way for script to determine the engine version it is running on
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot v2.1.beta

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When the editor is first started it displays the Godot version in the project selection window (eg: v2.1.beta or v2.1.beta.custom_build when git-n-scons'ed).  As pointed out on FB there is no current way for a script to determine the Godot version it is running on.  It would be according to Rémi Verschelde on FB, "easy to add and a good idea" to add a method somewhere a script may access to obtain this information.

**Steps to reproduce:**

```
# sample interface for obtaining version
func getGodotVersion():
    # OS object seems to be a good choice
    return OS.get_engine_version()  # this method currently does not exist
```

data.title: Refactoring: Code files to rename or split
data.body:
This is a brainstorming issue so that we can see what we'd like to rename/split when we start working on 3.0 (and thus will be allowed to break compatibility).
## Files to rename
- `core/path_db:*` -> `core/node_path.*`, to match their actual class
## Files to split
- `core/math_2d.*` -> `core/vector_2d.*`, + more as needed
- `tools/editor/editor_node.*` -> TODO, list potential split classes

data.title: Allow Position2D to have customizable area rects
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** All systems, Godot version 2.0.4.1 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected): Position2D can be used for positioning their child nodes; however, those nodes are positioned to the center of the Position2D. Position2D is ALWAYS 20x20 pixels. Therefore, if I have a Position2D at 0,0 with its children having no offset, its children will actually be at 10,10. This can be undesirable, especially if using grid snapping to non-multiples of 10. Obviously there are workarounds, but to be able to set the size of the Position2D rect - and thus the position at which its children will actually be - would be very useful.

**Steps to reproduce:** Place a Position2D node at 0,0. Turn Grid Snapping on. Add a child node of any type to the Position2D node, and set it also to 0,0. As you will see, it results in the child node being shown at 10,10.

MacOS: Moving Godot Editor Window from Retina Display to non Retina display does not resize the content appropriately
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.1 beta 20160712 osx

_**Not reproducible with 2.0 stable version**_ 

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When moving the window from a 'zoomed' monitor (Retina Display) to a non zoomed (Full HD) monitor the window content is too big

Retina before:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/36638/16836048/d6c9abbc-49bb-11e6-8bd1-caba83e196c3.png)

After moving to Non Retina Monitor:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/36638/16835999/9ed9e0aa-49bb-11e6-8cf2-705f5e937f2d.png)

**Steps to reproduce:**
(Using a MacBook Pro MBP)
- 1 External DVI monitor via Lightning Cable attached to MBP
- Start Godot on the Retina screen (Builtin screen) and open a project
- Move the window over to non retina screen

data.title: Collapsing / expanding node lists using the arrow keys
data.body: It's a simple thing, but since navigation on the list is possible using the Up / Down arrow keys, expanding and collapsing using the Left / Right arrow keys is the next intuitive thing people will try to do.

data.title: Node Addon parent won't list the Addon when searched on Node list
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux Mint 17.2 Cinnamon 64-bit - Godot 2.1 Beta

**Issue description**
After activating a Node kind of Addon, the node the Addon inherits from won't show it's children (the Addon) when searching for the Addon parent.

For example (and in the case I tested): a Node Addon that inherits from ReferenceFrame will appear on the Node list, but if you search for ReferenceFrame, the Node Addon won't be listed as a child.

**Steps to reproduce:**
I tested using the Addon I created before: https://github.com/henriquelalves/GodotTIE
Just activate the Addon and search for "ReferenceFrame" on the Node list.

data.title: FileSystem drag and drop can easily lead to missing dependencies issues
data.body:
**Windows 10 - Godot 2.1 :**

**fileSystem usability:**
After **accidental** moving of folders using the drag & drop feature from the fileSystem, along with a manual correction to re-parent my folders will not revert their new paths and cause missing dependencies issues. Having me needed to correct all my scripts, assets and scenes that got involved prior to moving.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Move folders into folders using drag & drop from the fileSystem; folders that contain assets that were attached to scenes.

**Suggestion:**
Alert user with a message when moving a folder that contain assets that were attached to node/scenes, changing them will cause missing dependencies, even manually reverting any changes.

data.title: ItemList - set_item_disabled() doesnt have any visible effect

_Bugsquad edit:_ Seen in 2.1-beta (but actually there too in 2.0)

It doesnt seem to do what it is supposed to.

Try it

```
func _on_ItemList_item_selected( index ):
    set_item_disabled(index,true)
```

or am i messing something up here? :)

data.title: Profiler: usability ideas
data.body:
After testing a bit the profiler, I have a few ideas to improve its usability:
- Ability to focus spikes more easily. Half of performance bottlenecks can be seen as spikes, and focusing them in the profiler is currently a bit tedious since you have to be pixel-perfect when clicking on the graph.
  Could we have zoom or something allowing easy precision?
- Functions taking most time should be ordered first instead of last, because they are the point of profiling. I see I can click on the headers but it does nothing particular.

data.title: Profiler: pausing the game opens the debugger even while profiling
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.1 beta, Windows 10 64 bits

When I use the profiler to monitor the game while it is running, if I hit pause the debugger tab opens and hides the profiler. I see the debugger could show stack frames but here it is empty and useless since I want to see the curves of the profiler. Is it an intended behaviour?

data.title: Profiler: curves are not updated when a checkbox is ticked
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.1 beta, Windows 10 64 bits

When I tick a checkbox in the list of functions of the profiler when the game is paused or profiling is stopped, the curve is not drawn. It is only updated when the game runs. This is not convenient when analyzing frames on a stopped graph.

data.title: Profiler: the checkboxes seem difficult to tick
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.1 beta, Windows 10 64 bits

When testing the debugger, I found that ticking the checkboxes that toggle curves are not very responsive, I often have to click several times on them, even when the game is paused or profiling is stopped.
However, no problem when the game doesn't runs.

data.title: Hot-reloading AtlasTexture causes infinite reload loop [2.1]
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 x64, Godot 2.1 beta x86

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
After saving image which loaded as AtlasTexture, Gotot catches up and tries to reimport texture, but **sometimes** this causes infinite texture reloading loop, I have got a video: https://gfycat.com/EvenThinDiplodocus
I have used Paint.NET to resave the image. Also I have my image stored outside of Godot project folder, I used Import window to import image as texture. Going back to project list and opening project again helps, console shows `condition 'rename_error' is true` at `drivers\windows\file_access_window.cpp:139`

**Steps to reproduce:**
Resave image which is saved as AtlasTexture, maybe there are issue with another texture types too, but I have never encoutered it. Sometimes after saving image this issue happens, not happens when just started up Godot.
